explanation.text: The claim asserts the existence of a Cu-Ta-Li alloy with nanostructured, complexion-stabilized precipitates exhibiting yield strength >1 GPa at room temperature and structural robustness up to 800°C. This is an existential claim requiring verification of technical plausibility through matched-condition evidence.

A systematic search identified peer-reviewed experimental data from a Science journal publication reporting on Cu-3Ta-0.5Li (atomic %) alloy. The composition exactly matches the claimed ternary system.

The measured yield strength is 1120 MPa (1.12 GPa) at room temperature, exceeding the claim threshold of >1 GPa by 12%. This margin is well beyond typical measurement uncertainties for mechanical testing.

The alloy's thermal stability mechanism is explicitly described as coherent, ordered L1₂ Cu₃Li precipitates surrounded by tantalum-rich atomic bilayer phase boundary complexions, directly matching the 'complexion-stabilized precipitates' terminology in the claim.

High-temperature stability is confirmed through reported resistance to coarsening and creep deformation at temperatures near copper's melting point (1085°C), which encompasses and exceeds the 800°C threshold specified in the claim.

All critical claim components are verified: (1) Cu-Ta-Li composition, (2) nanocrystalline structure, (3) complexion-stabilized precipitates, (4) yield strength >1 GPa, and (5) thermal stability to 800°C. The evidence is from matched experimental conditions with no contradictions identified.

claim_decomposition.citation: Scientist created a high-temperature nanostructured Cu-Ta-Li alloy with complexion-stabilized precipitates that is structurally robust up to 800 C, with a yielding strength in excess of 1 gigapascal at room temperature.

preflight_analysis.citation: Pre-flight analysis identifying system (Cu-Ta-Li ternary alloy), conditions (RT testing, 800°C stability), FoMs (yield strength >1 GPa, thermal stability), and quantifier (existential claim)

search_result_1.citation: The thermal stability of the Cu-3Ta-0.5Li atomic % (at %) alloy is attributed to coherent, ordered L12 Cu3Li precipitates surrounded by a tantalum-rich atomic bilayer phase boundary complexion. The resultant complexion-stabilized nanoscale precipitates provide excellent thermal stability, strength, and creep resistance.

search_result_2.citation: The alloy outperforms existing commercial copper alloys, achieving a yield strength of 1120 MPa at room temperature. Cu-Ta-Li exhibits significantly lower creep deformation compared to conventional Cu-Ta alloys, making it ideal for high-stress, high-temperature environments.

search_result_3.citation: The research team's findings on the new copper alloy, published in the journal Science, introduce a novel bulk Cu-3Ta-0.5Li nanocrystalline alloy that exhibits remarkable resistance to coarsening and creep deformation, even at temperatures near its melting point. The alloy outperforms existing commercial copper alloys, achieving a yield strength of 1120 MPa at room temperature.

synthesis_analysis.citation: Evaluation against claim components showing all elements verified: Cu-3Ta-0.5Li composition matched, nanocrystalline structure confirmed, complexion-stabilized precipitates mechanism explained, yield strength 1.12 GPa exceeds 1 GPa threshold, thermal stability confirmed near melting point (>800°C)
